qas.question: Why did Confucians hate the medical field?

context: The physicians of the Yuan court came from diverse cultures. Healers were divided into <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>non-Mongol physicians<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> called otachi and traditional Mongol shamans. The Mongols characterized otachi doctors by their use of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>herbal<a1_1/> remedies<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/>, which was distinguished from the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>spiritual<a2_2/><a2_1/> cures<b7_0/><a2_0/> of Mongol shamanism. Physicians received official support from the Yuan government and were given special legal privileges. Kublai created the <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>Imperial Academy of Medicine<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> to manage medical treatises and the education of new doctors. Confucian scholars were attracted to the medical profession because <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>it ensured a high income and medical ethics were compatible with Confucian virtues<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
